citation.article-title: Rearrangements of the species and genera of the phototrophic "purple nonsulfur bacteria."

p.s: Emendation of genus Rhodopseudomuonas Kluyver and van Niel in Czurda and Maresch 1937.

Type species: Rhodopseudomonas palustris (Molisch 1907) van Niel 1944. Other species: Rhodopseudomonas viridis Drews and Giesbrecht 1966, Rhodopseudomonas acidophila Pfennig 1969, Rhodopseudomonas sulfoviridis Keppen and Gorlenko 1975, Rhodopseudomonas blastica Eckersley and Dow 1981, Rhodopseudomonas rutila Akiba et al. 1983 (2), and Rhodopseudomonas marina Imhoff 1983. Species removed from this genus: Rhodopseudomonas capsulata (Molisch 1907) van Niel 1944, Rhodopseudomonas sphaeroides van Niel 1944, Rhodopseudomonas gelatinosa (Molisch 1907) van Niel 1944, Rhodopseudomonas sulfidophila Hansen and Veldkamp 1973, Rhodopseudomonas globiformis Pfennig 1974, and Rhodopseudomonas adriatica Neutzling et al. 1984.

Cells are rod shaped, show polar growth, asymmetrical division, or budding as a mode of reproduction, are motile by means of flagella, and have intracytoplasmic membranes that are adjacent and parallel to the cytoplasmic membrane.

Growth factor requirements and sensitivity to oxygen are different in the various species. Rhodopseudomonas viridis and Rhodopseudomonas acidophila have a small type of cytochrome c2; Rhodopseudomonas palustris differs from these species by containing different cytochromes and by the presence of a large type of cytochrome c2.
The cytochrome structures of the other species in this genus are not known.

Studies of lipopolysaccharides have revealed 2,3-diamino-2,3-dideoxyglucose as an unique structural component of Rhodopseudomonas viridis, Rhodopseudomonas sulfoviridis, and Rhodopseudomonas palustris, but not of Rhodopseudomonas marina.
Data on the lipopolysaccharide structures of the other species are not available.

The quinones present in the various species of this genus are also different. Rhodopseudomonas palustris and Rhodopseudomonas blastica have Q-10 as the sole quinone component, whereas Rhodopseudomonas acidophila and Rhodopseudomonas marina have MK-10 in addition.
The quinones of the other species differ in the length of the isoprenoid chain.

So far four species have been analyzed with respect to the pathway of sulfate assimilation; Rhodopseudomonas palustris and Rhodopseudomonas viridis reduce 3'-phosphate adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate, Rhodopseudomonas acidophila reduces adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate, and Rhodopseudomonas sulfoviridis is not able to reduce sulfate at all.
From 16s rRNA studies it is known that Rhodopseudomonas palustris and Rhodopseudomonas viridis have similar oligonucleotide catalogs.

Hybridization studies of DNA and rRNA have led to the arrangement of Rhodopseudomonas palustris, Rhodopseudomonas viridis, and Rhodopseudomonas acidophila on one branch of “superfamily IV,” whereas Rhodopseudomonas blastica is placed on another branch of this superfamily together with the species included in the new genus Rhodobacter.
Because of its morphological properties and since other conflicting results are lacking, Rhodopseudomonas blastica is retained in the genus Rhodopseudomonas.

The recently described species Rhodopseudomonas rutila is classified with this genus on the basis of its polar growth and budding, as well as its lamellar intracytoplasmic membranes, which are parallel to the cytoplasmic membrane.

Cell shape, mode of growth, and reproduction, as well as the structure of the intracytoplasmic membranes, are the characteristic properties that allow unequivocal classification of new species in this genus.
